short_answer.body: Write a short statement about the nature of question writing.

Suppose that you read an article in the newspaper that reports on a study that establishes a "link" between coffee consumption and road rage. Suppose the article reports that in a national survey, people who report drinking 4 or more cups of coffee a day also report being involved in twice as many road rage incidents as people who drink 2 cups or less. Write a paragraph or two in which you discuss the study from the perspective of observation vs. intervention.

response.feedback: Compare your answer to ours: The study reports on a national survey in which people were asked about their coffee drinking habits and road rage, but not intervened upon to drink a certain amount of coffee or intervened upon to have a certain amount of road rage. This is a clear case of observation, not intervention. We might be able to predict that someone who drinks a lot of coffee is more likely to experience road rage than someone who drinks only a little coffee, but that does NOT mean we can predict what would happen if we intervened upon heavy coffee drinkers to consume only a cup a day. It might be the case that people who are just easy to enrage are also people who like to drink a lot of coffee. Or it might be that drinking a lot of coffee causes people to be more susceptible to road rage. It would be interesting to see what would happen in an experiment in which some people were forced to drink only 1 cup a day and others were forced to drink 4 cups a day. If, in that case, the heavy coffee drinkers had more road rage, then we would be in a much better position to conclude that the "link" between coffee drinking and road rage is causal.
